These include wide range of legacy APIs, user exits, BadIs and established frameworks like SAP GUI and ABAP list viewer grid.

Level C – Extensions at Level C involve the use of SAP internal objects that are not classified or intended for customer use. These objects are neither officially released, recommended, nor cloud-ready, and they fall outside SAP’s formal support scope. However, with the introduction of the new changelog for SAP objects (currently in work and will become later available), customers can proactively analyze and plan for potential upgrade impacts when Level C objects are affected by incompatible changes. For this reason, Level C extensions are considered conditionally clean.

Level D – Classified as not clean core. This level includes extensions that don’t follow SAP’s guidelines, such as system modifications, reliance on non-recommended SAP objects, or unsupported techniques like implicit enhancements.

Below table explains the differences in each level for comparison.

For detailed guidance on frameworks, technologies and development patterns in the context of clean core extensibility, please refer to SAP Note: 3578329.

4. HOW to find SAP extensibility objects classification by levels:

The “SAP Business Accelerator Hub” and “Cloudification Repository (API Viewer)” are the central tools to classify objects by clean core level. It shows which objects are:

  • Released APIs (Level A)
  • Classic APIs (Level B)
  • No APIs (Level D)
  • Internal Objects (Level C – default when not classified as A, B and D)

The SAP API Business Hub is SAP’s central catalog of APIs, integration content, and business services. All the APIs are classified as Level A. Remote APIs are for consumption in BTP and local APIs are for consumption in “On-stack extensibility”.

The Cloudification Repository Viewer is an interactive tool designed to help developers explore API details for “SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public” and “SAP S/4HANA Private Edition” for on-stack extensions.

Links:

  • SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition
  • SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition (Doesn’t include Classic APIs)
  • SAP S/4 HANA Cloud Private Edition (Classic API’s)

In this article, I will be demonstrating the usage of “S/4 HANA Cloud Private Edition”.

4.1 Extension Level A

The cleanest form of custom extensions. These are built either directly on-stack with the ABAP Cloud development model or side-by-side on SAP BTP using SAP Build, whether through ABAP Cloud, CAP, or low-code/no-code tools. You can find the released API’s at SAP Business Accelerator Hub. If you are a developer, you can find the released API’s directly in the IDE (Integrated Development Environment).

 Alternatively, for “SAP S/4 HANA Cloud Private Edition" you can follow the below steps.

Detailed Steps:

1. Go to S/4 HANA Cloud ERP Private  (Doesn’t include Classic APIs)
2. Click “Show Filter Bar”

3. Choose “Released” under State drop down.

4. You have different options to filter results based on “Object type”, “Software Component” and “Application Component”

5. You can also search for objects (Example of search results for “purchase_order”)

4.2 Extension Level B – Classics APIs:

Extensions that follow SAP’s best practices for classic ABAP development and use only officially provided SAP APIs and frameworks. These extensions can be used only if the requirements cannot be fulfilled by set of released APIs (Level A). These include wide range of legacy APIs, user exits, BadIs and established frameworks like SAP GUI and ABAP list viewer grid.

Detailed Steps on finding the Classic API’s:

  1. Go to S/4 HANA Cloud Private Edition (Classic API’s)
  2. Click “Show Filter Bar”

3. Choose “Classic API” in the state 

4. You can choose filter criteria as needed

5. You can also search for objects (Example of search results for “sales”)

4.3 Extension Level C – Conditionally Clean

Extensions at Level C involve the use of SAP internal objects that are not classified or intended for customer use. These objects are neither officially released, recommended, nor cloud-ready, and they fall outside SAP’s formal support scope. However, with the introduction of the new changelog for SAP objects (currently in work and will become later available), customers can proactively analyze and plan for potential upgrade impacts when Level C objects are affected by incompatible changes. For this reason, Level C extensions are considered conditionally clean.

  • You can find objects in Level A (Released APIs), Level B (Classical APIs) and Level D (No APIs).

Level C refers to all internal SAP objects that are neither “Released APIs,” “Classical APIs,” nor “APIs” at all. Since they are internal objects, no official list exists.

4.4 Extension Level D – Not Clean Core

Extensions at level D are classified as not clean core. These includes extensions that doesn’t follow SAP’s guidelines, such as system modifications, reliance on non-recommended SAP objects, or unsupported techniques like implicit enhancements.

Detailed Steps on finding objects which are “Not APIs” classified as “No APIs”

  1. Go to S/4 HANA Cloud Private Edition (Classic API’s)
  2. Click “Show Filter Bar

3. Choose “No API” in State

4. Results with “No APIs” are displayed

5. Successor information is available for some of the objects.

5. Summary:
With this evolved model, SAP is giving organizations a smarter playbook for extension decisions. By aligning with clean core principles on a clear scale (Levels A, B, C and D), businesses can innovate faster, keep their systems future-ready, and reduce technical debt—while still getting the flexibility they need today.

6. References:

No

entry.title: Never ever remove an IAM app from a Business Catalog
entry.content:
Never ever remove an IAM app from a Business Catalog!!!

As soon as such a Business Catalog change is published, as per SAP, "all roles need to be processed to ensure consistency since the data does not have a link anymore between the removed IAM apps and the affected catalogs."

Yes, it processes all roles in the system

In our case, it was 6000 roles in the system. As you can see, the publishing/unpublishing jobs have been running for 7 days now and still continuing. We have been in touch with SAP Support. Their explanation of how publishing works: "In general, it works like this: if a publishing process A is triggered, it is processed right away. If during this process new publishing processes B and C are triggered, this is added to a queue until the publishing process A from before is done. Then B and C will be processed together. Now, if there are 10 or 20 of them queued up, they all will be processed together and depending on the objects, this can take longer. "

There were 30-40 processes running in the system at the beginning. Now after 7 days, it has reduced to 11 processes. It locked up all the business roles for changes during the publishing process - Security team can't make any updates to roles for several days. Developers couldn't create new apps/communication scenarios/services etc. in the system. 

So, what is the workaround for this if someone really wants to remove an IAM app from a Business Catalog? The only way I could think of, is to create a brand-new Business Catalog and move whatever apps that are really needed into the new one. But, what if few months down the line, someone wants to remove another app from that 2nd Business Catalog? ... and so on...

Does this mean, to avoid all this trouble, developers should be allowed to have only one IAM app per Business Catalog? Are there any other possible ideas?

entry.title: 🟡 Introducing the Devtoberfest Scavenger Hunt 🔨🪙 ... COMING SOON
entry.content:
Welcome to the Devtoberfest Scavenger Hunt, a chase around important SAP developer-related tools/sites, a challenge to construct a secret phrase, and a chance to win 1000s of points toward the Devtoberfest grand prize.

The hunt officially starts Sept. 25, with the release of the first clue during that day's SAP Developer News, and you have until the end of Devtoberfest, Oct. 24, to complete it.

To get all the clues make sure to SUBSCRIBE TO THIS POST!!

Learn more about the  entire Devtoberfest event in @KevinR's post Devtoberfest 2025 Welcome!.

What you need to find

We have hidden a special phrase, which you need to figure out using the clues from several missions, described in the next section. Along your journey you will do the following:

  1. Visit about 10 different locations related to SAP developers, mostly web sites that are designed to help you in your daily SAP development.
  2. At each location, you will discover a set of hexadecimal digits.
  3. Concatenate the digits together (in the order of the missions) to get one, 37-digit hexadecimal number.
  4. Multiply that hexadecimal number by another secret number, for which we will give a clue.
  5. Take the resulting 38-digit hexadecimal product, and convert it into the secret phrase, using each pair of digits as values for ASCII characters.
  6. Enter the phrase, exactly (case-sensitive, no extra spaces), into the Scavenger Hunt tutorial.‌

Not until the SAP Developer News of Oct. 16 will you have all the pieces to be able to complete the phrase. 

Example Hunt

As an example of what you will have to do, here's a short sample hunt (just a warm-up, no points will be earned). Each mission is independent of the other.

MissionNo. DigitsSAP Web PropertyInstructions
17

SAP Developers YouTube Channel

Go to our SAP Developer YouTube channel. 

Open @Rekha_DR's video "SAP Build Process Automation (Part 1): Build your very first process". Watch it and find the secret 7-digit hexadecimal number in one of the info cards.

You can also see the hex digits in the description.

26SAP Community

Inside this blog post, use the Developer Tools on your browser to inspect the words "SAP Community" in the cell immediately to the left (in this very table) and find the 6-digit RGB ASCII code for the color of the text. 

3None (directly) 

Concatenate the 2 sets of hexadecimal digits (13 in all), in order, and multiply the resulting hexadecimal number by the number of original SAP founders (you can easily find the number on the SAP Wikipedia page).

Convert the resulting hexadecimal number into a phrase, converting each pair of digits into a character using ASCII codes.

👉In this blog post, post a comment/picture about the phrase -- but NOT the phrase itself  (like your experiences with or opinion about the phrase, or a picture of something belonging to you that reminds you of the phrase). You won't get any points, but it will be fun and you will be ready for the real scavenger hunt. If you have any trouble with this example hunt, post in the comments.

REMINDER: The above is just an example of how the real scavenger hunt will work. The real scavenger hunt instructions will be described in the rest of this blog post, as clues become available.

 

The (real) hunt

Below are the instructions for finding the hexadecimal digits for the actual scavenger hunt. We will release clues as follows:

  • In the SAP Developer News of Sept. 25, Oct. 2, Oct. 9, and Oct. 16.
  • In this blog each Monday during the first 3 weeks of Devtoberfest.

👉To be notified when a new clue is released, SUBSCRIBE TO THIS POST!!

‌ When you find the secret phase, just enter it into this Devtoberfest tutorial.

To guide you, we have created a second tutorial -- you do not have to use it, nor do you get any points from it. But you can enter the 1 to 6 digits from each mission to check if you received the correct digits for that mission.

Here are your missions 

MissionNo. DigitsSAP Web PropertyInstructions
12

SAP Developer News

The Developer News comes out each Thursday with the latest about ABAP, CAP, BTP, SAP Build, UI5, Fiori, AI, and all your favorite SAP developer topics. All delivered by some of your favorite Developer Advocates, like DJ, Shilpa Shankar, Thomas Jung, Antonio Maradiaga, Nora von Thenen and the rest of the gang.

Most episodes about 5 minutes. Also available as a Podcast.

Watch the Developer News of Sept. 25
26 To be released Sept. 29
34 To be released Sept. 29
42 Watch the Developer News of Oct. 2
54 To be released Oct. 6
66 To be released Oct. 6
76 Watch the Developer News of Oct. 9
86 To be released Oct. 13
91 To be released Oct. 13
10None (directly) Watch the Developer News of Oct. 16

Good luck!

😸

entry.title: Deep Dive and Experience Sharing into SAP Joule for Developers(J4D)
entry.content:
Disclaimer: This blog is not written by any LLM.

Well, to start with, Joule for Developers, let us understand what it is?

Many people have a misconception that Joule for Developers or J4D is just an ABAP AI capability. But it is much more beyond ABAP. Joule for Developers(J4D) is collective name for the AI-powered design-time capabilities across SAP Build and ABAP

It includes new and existing features enabled by Joule in:

  1. SAP Build Code
  2. SAP Build Apps
  3. SAP Build Process Automation
  4. ABAP in SAP BTP and S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition

These capabilities help developers build faster, code smarter, and automate better. Is that true? I will my honest opinion for some of them.

I have personally worked on SAP Build Apps, SAP Build Code and Joule for Developers, ABAP AI. I started with a lot of ambiguity and finally I made a mark that I could now explain it to our customers and users.

SAP Build Apps allow for generating pages to handle data entities and generate sample data automatically. It means, whenever you integrate any oData service/REST API/SAP BTP Destination, you get an option to automatically create the User Interface and also generate sample data.

SAP Build Code, has evolved through multiple iterations and seems it is still evolving. 

  • Created Fiori element app using Image
  • Created a series of projects with prompts
  • Created test data

With ABAP AI, I could create a report with the suggestions popping up in run time and that too contextually aware code prompts also known to be predictive code completion feature. We called it Ghost Code. But trust me sometimes they are really good too. 

I see the ABAP and CDS unit scripts getting generated in no time. It was good again on this parameter. 

Code explain, well I created small projects, hence feel it is good to have comments. But the true colors will be visible when you look at the repository of thousands lines of code written by someone and you have no clue of what it is. Using your skills you debug the code to understand what each block/function is doing. It is a life saver in this scenario.

SAP Build Code has the GenAI embedded as part of the service itself. There is no explicit step which need to perform other than just subscribing to this service via the Boosters (from the SAP BTP Global Account).

For SAP Build Apps and SAP Build Process Automation, everything under the new SAP Build Offering, will have the GenAI capability turned off by default. Then, how do you turn it on?

  1. Go to your SAP BTP Subaccount and access the SAP Build Apps and SAP Build Process Automation service from the 'Instances and Subscription' option
  2. SAP Build Lobby will openStep 1 - Access SAP Build Lobby

  3. Now go to the 'Control Tower' in the right hand side panel, last option and then click on the 'Generative AI' tile in the top row, right hand side 'Tenant Configuration'Step 2 - Click on Control Tower Option in Left Hand Pane

  4. Switch on the toggle button of Generative AI
    Step 3 - Click on Generative AI tile in the right hand pane

  5. Read the AI Terms and Conditions and scroll to the bottom of the Terms and Conditions to enable the checkbox of 'I have read the terms and conditions' - this is called as 'Scroll wrap agreement' in the language of Law - it means you agree to the Terms and Conditions and read till the last of the agreement.

    Step 5 - Read/Scroll to the end of the AI Terms & Conditions

  6. Click on the checkbox of 'I have read the terms and conditions'  

    Step 6 - Click on 'Accept' button on the right hand bottom corner

  7. Now click on the 'Accept' button 

    Step 4 - Turn on the toggle of Enable Generative AI features

  8. That's it. Now you can explore the GenAI capability inside SAP Build Apps and SAP Build Process Automation.

Some people have questions whether they need to sign a 0 USD AI Terms and Conditions contract to activate the GenAI capability for J4D. The answer is, except for 'Joule for Developers ABAP AI' capability, you do NOT need to sign an explicit contract for AI Terms and Conditions. They are all embedded within the services.

Well this will be an evolving document, where I will keep updating my reviews on each of these services mentioned. Stay tuned!

entry.title: Introducing SAP Application Extension Methodology version 2.4
entry.content:
Exploring the SAP BTP Guidance Framework - Extensibility

I am pleased to announce the availability of the SAP Application Extension Methodology version 2.4. In this blog post, I would like to provide a quick overview and highlight the changes in this newest release.

For a quick introduction to the methodology, please take a look here: SAP Application Extension Methodology.

This blog post is part of the series SAP BTP Guidance Framework: A Compass for Architects, Developers, and Administrators.

The SAP BTP Guidance Framework is a practical framework tailored to anyone using the SAP Business Technology Platform. SAP BTP acts as the technological backbone for building, integrating, extending, and innovating with SAP solutions. Whether you're an enterprise architect, software developer, or administrator, SAP BTP offers significant opportunities for productivity and development.

 

What’s New for SAP Application Extension Methodology

With the SAP Application Extension Methodology version 2.4, we have made some changes to the Extension Technology Mapping. We now include the Clean Core Level concept directly in the Mapping, allowing you to easily follow the latest guidance. Next to each Technical Extension Building Block, you can find the corresponding Clean Core Level (A-D).

SAP Application Extension Methodology - Extension Technology Mapping with Clean Core Levels

Please be aware that the single source of truth for the Clean Core Levels is the official SAP Note 3578329. 

If you are still using an older version of the Technology Mapping, I highly recommend checking out our new version and to learn about the latest innovations and technologies on SAP S/4HANA and SAP Business Technology Platform.

 

Clean Core Level Concept in a Nutshell

Clean Core Levels Overview

TL;DR

  • Always develop your extension with the highest clean core level.
  • Leverage released APIs and best practice classic APIs of Level A and B to be clean core compliant.
  • Avoid not recommended SAP objects of Level D as they are not clean core compliant.

Level A

Level A is considered clean core and your strategic direction. You develop extension with SAP Build either on-stack on SAP S/4HANA and/or Side-by-Side on SAP BTP. Usually, you use a combination of both. You will use ABAP Cloud, CAP and our low-code/no-code tools in SAP Build. You can find the released APIs and extensions points on the SAP Business Accelerator Hub.

Level B

Level B is considered clean core. You use upgrade stable classic APIs, which you can find in the cloudification repository viewer with filter state = classic API.

Level C

Level C is considered conditionally clean. Use the internal SAP objects only if needed. There is no guarantee on long-term stability. Apply the changelog for SAP objects to mitigate upgrade risks.

Level D

Level D is considered NOT clean core. Those objects are unfit for customer use. You can find them in the cloudification repository viewer with filter state = noAPI.

 

Next Steps:

Learn more about the SAP Application Extension Methodology on the SAP Help Portal.

Learn more about the SAP BTP Guidance Framework on the SAP Discovery Center and look out for the continuation of the blog post series. The next one will be about Data&Analytics.

Learn more about Clean Core by reading our detailed whitepaper, or tune into our latest Unlocking SAP BTP podcast episode focusing on clean core.

Feel free to like, comment and ask your questions!

Talk to you soon,
Marco

Product Manager SAP Business Technology Platform

Join me online: https://www.linkedin.com/in/marcomatha/

entry.title: ABAP AI - Chapter 2
entry.content:
Summary

  • New ABAP AI capabilities keep coming
  • Joule for Developers, ABAP AI capabilities remain free of charge
  • Availability of ABAP AI in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition in release 2025 is ahead of us
  • ABAP AI will be available in older releases of SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition as well, details and updates expected at TechEd.

In February 2025, we started the first chapter of ABAP AI and announced that Joule speaks ABAP. Now, it’s time to get ready for chapter 2!

In the past months, we have been delivering more Joule skills to speed up ABAP Cloud development, and we are now able to create RAP business objects – from the database table up to the UI service powered by generative AI. We can create unit tests, explain code, complete code in the editor, implement validations and determinations, and much more (see also our public slide deck). All these skills are part of the 2508 release of SAP BTP ABAP Environment and SAP Cloud ERP (SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition), and they will be included in the SAP Cloud ERP Private (SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition) in the 2025 release. Please check out our updated tutorial on ABAP AI capabilities. In addition, we will continue to expand our AI scope and will deliver on the transformation aspect of our AI strategy. This starts with the 2025 delivery for SAP Cloud ERP Private, followed by AI capabilities in the custom code migration app in SAP BTP ABAP Environment 2602. Please visit our roadmap to keep track of our deliveries.

Let’s continue with commercials and keep it short: The free promotions we introduced at the beginning of the year have been extended until further notice! We are convinced that, in the current situation, we don’t want to put any commercial barriers on our offering and let all customers and partners benefit from AI-driven development. The corresponding material numbers for customers 8019124 and TDD partners 8019541 remain the same and can be ordered again. For those who started before the extension of the promotion, note that a re-ordering of the material is required. The procedure for the SAP BTP ABAP Environment and SAP Cloud ERP remains the same as well, and the initial blog post has been updated to reflect this, as well as SAP Note 3571857.
For SAP Cloud ERP Private, as of release 2025, the material numbers are also valid. However, the configuration will need to be done manually by you. Detailed information on this will follow.

But that is not enough. Will ABAP AI capabilities become available also for older releases of SAP Cloud ERP Private? Yes!
Imagine an ABAP AI service running side-by-side to your ABAP instance, providing full access to ABAP AI capabilities across hybrid landscapes. This includes SAP BTP ABAP Environment, SAP Cloud ERP, and SAP Cloud ERP Private. New AI innovations become available independently of release upgrades or support packages, allowing immediate leveraging.  Best of all, this ABAP AI service can also be connected to older releases of SAP Cloud ERP Private.

Sounds like a dream? Let’s find out – stay tuned for TechEd 2025 to receive all the news and updates!

The Custom Fields and Logic app has been deprecated in favor of the Custom Logic (App ID: F6957) app in SAP S/4HANA. In present we are using Custom Logic Fiori app to implement Business Add-Ins (BAdIs) and behavior extensions for released business objects.

This blog aims to assist you in adding preconditions (such as Account Assignment, Plant, and Cost Centre) for Manage Workflows for Purchase Requisitions Fiori App. These standard fields must be displayed in the F4 help or dropdown menu for selection. Step 12 –Write your logic for second BAdI like the below Code snippets:

entry.title: Using the SAP EarlyWatch Alert Status App
entry.content:
SAP Note 1257308 - FAQ: Using EarlyWatch Alert provides preliminary information about the Status App. The app tracks the status of the SAP EarlyWatch Alert (EWA) from the arrival of service data through all processing steps at SAP. This app is intended for administrators to troubleshoot the EWA process. This blog will provide a more detailed description of the Status App functionality.

EWA session data can be sent to SAP through various methods. The EWA session data can be sent directly to SAP through the HTTP destination SAP-SUPPORT_PORTAL (via SAP-SUPPORT_PARCELBOX) from either an ABAP managed system or an SAP Solution Manager system. Additionally, any EWA session data for systems managed by the ECS team are sent via their SAP Focused Run systems on SAP side to be processed. The following Notes and KBAs are provided for more information on all three scenarios.

  • 207223 - SAP EarlyWatch Alert Processed at SAP
  • 1684537 - EarlyWatch Alert Not Sent to SAP: Troubleshooting Guide - SAP Solution Manager
  • 2930644 - SAP Focused Run: EarlyWatch Alert Troubleshooting Guide - Guided Answer

After sending EWA session data through one of the available methods it can be unclear whether the EWA data was successfully received by SAP or if there was any issue with the EWA session processing. The EWA Status App allows you to follow the status of your EWA report once it’s sent to SAP.

All EWA session data sent to SAP will be available for review in the EWA Status App, here you will find various details about the EWA sessions you have sent.

You can see the date the EWA session data session was sent, if they have been successfully received by SAP, as well as whether the EWA session could be processed successful or has been generated and posted in the EWA workspace.

Since the EWA session data packages sent to SAP are processed in randomly assigned batches for all customers it can take from a few hours to a few days for your EWA result to be available in various SAP applications like the EWA Workspace, Solution Finder, EWA Dashboard, or as a Word document available for download. Using the Status App allows you to track this process without opening a case.

The general fields available in the EWA Status App that are applicable for all system types are the following columns.

  • System
  • Product
  • Sending System Product
  • Data Received at SAP
  • Collected At

The “System” and “Product” columns will list the long and short SID as well as the product version respectively of the EWA target system.

The “Sending System Product” column, however, will display the product version of the system that transferred the session data to SAP. This is most often a Solution Manager or Focused Run system.  

Finally, the “Data Received at SAP” and “Collected at” columns document the date and time the EWA session package was received by SAP as well as when it was collected on the managed system.

Data Transfer Status Details

In the EWA Status App the “Data Transfer Status Details” column can have one of three status’. The status’ are Rejected, Ignored, Success. As you would expect Success simply indicates the EWA session data was successfully transferred to SAP. The other two status’ can be indicative of various errors. I will describe the most common in more detail below.

"Ignored (duplicate)"

This status indicates that the EWA is sent multiple times per week for the same system. You should check to see if the EWA is being sent from both Solution Manager and the managed system. The same checks should be performed for on prem FRUN systems. The EWA could also be sent multiple times per week from the same system. All will result in the same status.

"Ignored (not in allow list)"

This status can be caused by a few errors. However, the most common would be that either the license or maintenance certificate for the system is expired.

Recommendation:

Review the SLICENSE transaction in Solution Manager if used as well as the managed system to ensure both are up to date.

"Rejected (system time in future)"

The system runs with a system time deviating from official time. 

Recommendation:

The System Time can be synced manually by your system Admin. However, it is likely that this is a temporary change for testing purposes and it will sync automatically via Internet. If not working, your Admin can start this sync process at the OS Level.

 

"Rejected (no data)"

The service data that arrived at SAP is either not readable or empty or incomplete and thus important parts are completely missing.

Recommendation:

This would indicate that there are issues with EWA session data collection or service data quality. We recommend reviewing the resolution steps in the KBA 1824881 - Summary of Grey Rated EWA Reports - SAP Solution Manager.

"Rejected (non-productive)"

Only for productive and test systems the EWA is processed at SAP. Based on the system role the service data can be rejected. This is true for managed systems before ST-PI 740 SP23 (ST-PI 2008_1_7xx SP33) more information on the adjusted criteria can be found in SAP Note 207223 - SAP EarlyWatch Alert Processed at SAP.

"Rejected (not authorized)"

The technical communication user used for upload is not authorized to upload for this system.

Or

The technical communication user used for upload is not valid anymore.

Or

The user used for upload is not a technical communication user.

Recommendation:

You will need to ensure the S user assigned to both the SAP-SUPPORT_PORTAL and SAP-SUPPORT_PACELBOX HTTP destinations is a valid technical user. The following KBA outlines the requirements for the assigned user.

2174416 - Creation and activation of Technical Communication Users - SAP for Me

"Rejected (other reason)"

Create a case with component SV-SCS-EWA-GEN.

"Rejected (content size exceeds limit)"

The service data exceeds the size limit.

"Rejected (unknown system type)"

Supported technical system types are ABAP, HANA, JAVA and BOBJ. When extracting the leading system from the service data either no technical system type was determined, or the technical system type is not supported by EarlyWatch Alert.

Recommendation:

If using Solution Manager it is recommended that you review the system information maintained in LMDB. Ensure the technical system type is maintained and that it is a supported type.

In addition, in some scenarios is may be required to replace the SDCCN service definitions. The following KBA outlines the process and under which circumstances these steps should be performed.

SAP KBA 1765141 - When should the Service Definitions be completely replaced (Delete and Download) using the steps outlined in SAP Note 727998?

"Rejected (data too old)"

The service data that was sent to SAP was collected more than 112 days ago. Such old service data is not processed by SAP.

 

Details on Report Status, Dashboard Status, and Solution Finder Status

These three columns are relatively binary. The Status can either be “Success” or “Missing” / blank. In rare instances you can receive the status “Error (Initialization Failed)”. In this instance a case should be opened in the SV-SMG-SER-EWA component area.

The Report Status will be successful when the EWA document has been successfully generated. Until this point this column will remain blank. As mentioned previously it can take from a few hours to several days for your EWA result to be available. If the EWA session data was successfully received by SAP there is no cause for concern if the EWA report is not immediately available.

The same is true of the columns “Dashboard Status” and “Solution Finder Status”. When these applications are fully populated the EWA column status here in the Status App will change to Success. Prior to this the status will remain either blank or have the status “Missing”. Neither status is a cause for concern. If after several days the status of these columns remains unpopulated you should open a case in the SV-SMG-SER-EWA component area.

 

2 Billion Record Limit Status and Number Range Forecast Details

This column is system dependent. These checks are in reference to the maximum table size for HANA systems. The maximum table size cannot exceed 2 billion records for a HANA system without detrimental impact to the system.

However, the status “Missing” is most often applied to systems that do not have a HANA component. This information is not relevant to your system if you do not have a HANA Component and is not a cause for concern. You should review the EWA for the affected system to confirm that there is no associated HANA DB.

For HANA systems where this check was not successfully performed the status will instead be “No Forecast”, “Partial Success”, or “Unconfident Forecast”.

These may be a cause for concern and your first steps should be to review the RTCCTOOL recommendations of both the managed system and Solution Manager. You are looking for any red warning objects related to HANA session data, ST-PI, or ST-A/PI.

More information about the exact limitations of HANA are documented in the KBA 2154870 - How-To: Understanding and defining SAP HANA Limitations.

Additionally, more information can be found in the HANA Sizing Blog.

entry.title: Excel Upload/ Download Template/ Download Processed Data in SAP Fiori Without SAPUI5 - Using SAP RAP
entry.content:
In many projects, there is a common requirement to develop utilities for mass creation or update of business objects such as Purchase Orders, Materials, Sales Orders, Billing Documents etc. With the adoption of SAP S/4HANA, customers are increasingly opting for SAP Fiori applications over traditional classical reports for such use cases.

A frequent question arises:
Can we develop a Fiori application to upload files without building a custom SAPUI5 front end?
Yes, we can!

Thanks to SAP’s RESTful Application Programming (RAP) model and the use of specific annotations, it is possible to handle file uploads directly within a Fiori Elements application. No need for custom UI5 development.

To enable file uploads in RAP, the following annotation is crucial:

@Semantics.largeObject

This annotation allows handling of large file content (LOBs) in the RAP model. However, there is one important requirement:
You need to create a dedicated database table to store the uploaded file as a large object.

In below Example, I am explaining how Billing Date can be changed through Mass Upload.

In Excel Template I have two columns
Billing Document
New Billing date (DD.MM.YYYY)

Let’s walk through the steps to implement this.

Create Database and Draft Tables

We will begin by creating two database tables and their respective draft tables:

  1. Parent Table – Stores file metadata and the file content itself (LOB).
  2. Child Table – Stores the extracted data from the uploaded file. In this example, we will process an XLSX file.
Parent Table – ZTOM_T_USER

This table will store the uploaded file and its metadata. Here’s a sample structure:

@EndUserText.label : 'User Table for Excel Processing'
@AbapCatalog.enhancement.category : #NOT_EXTENSIBLE
@AbapCatalog.tableCategory : #TRANSPARENT
@AbapCatalog.deliveryClass : #A
@AbapCatalog.dataMaintenance : #ALLOWED
define table ztom_t_user {
  key mandt             : mandt not null;
  key end_user          : syuname not null;
  status                : abap.char(20);
  attachment            : ztom_de_attach;
  mimetype              : abap.char(128);
  filename              : abap.char(128);
  local_created_by      : abp_creation_user;
  local_created_at      : abp_creation_tstmpl;
  local_last_changed_by : abp_locinst_lastchange_user;
  local_last_changed_at : abp_locinst_lastchange_tstmpl;
  last_changed_at       : abp_lastchange_tstmpl;

}

This setup ensures the uploaded file can be stored as a RAWSTRING (LENGTH 0) in the backend.

 

Parent Draft Table – ZTOM_T_USERD
@EndUserText.label : 'User Draft Table for Excel Processing'
@AbapCatalog.enhancement.category : #NOT_EXTENSIBLE
@AbapCatalog.tableCategory : #TRANSPARENT
@AbapCatalog.deliveryClass : #A
@AbapCatalog.dataMaintenance : #ALLOWED
define table ztom_t_userd {
  key mandt             : mandt not null;
  key end_user          : syuname not null;
  status                : abap.char(20);
  attachment            : ztom_de_attach;
  mimetype              : abap.char(128);
  filename              : abap.char(128);
  local_created_by      : abp_creation_user;
  local_created_at      : abp_creation_tstmpl;
  local_last_changed_by : abp_locinst_lastchange_user;
  local_last_changed_at : abp_locinst_lastchange_tstmpl;
  last_changed_at       : abp_lastchange_tstmpl;
  "%admin"              : include sych_bdl_draft_admin_inc;

}

 

Child Table – ZTOM_T_EXCEL

This table will store the extracted data from the uploaded file. In this example, we will process an XLSX file. Here’s a sample structure:

@EndUserText.label : 'Excel Data Table'
@AbapCatalog.enhancement.category : #NOT_EXTENSIBLE
@AbapCatalog.tableCategory : #TRANSPARENT
@AbapCatalog.deliveryClass : #A
@AbapCatalog.dataMaintenance : #ALLOWED
define table ztom_t_excel {
  key mandt    : mandt not null;
  @AbapCatalog.foreignKey.screenCheck : false
  key end_user : syuname not null
    with foreign key ztom_t_user
      where end_user = ztom_t_excel.end_user;
  key vbeln    : vbeln_vf not null;
  new_fkdat    : abap.char(10);
  prev_fkdat   : abap.char(10);
  type         : bapi_mtype;
  message      : bapi_msg;

}

Parent Interface View – ZCDS_TOM_I_USER
@AccessControl.authorizationCheck: #NOT_REQUIRED
@EndUserText.label: 'Interface View - Excel User'
@Metadata.allowExtensions: true

define root view entity ZCDS_TOM_I_USER
  as select from    usr02       as _user
    left outer join ztom_t_user as _XLUser on _user.bname = _XLUser.end_user
  composition [0..*] of ZCDS_TOM_I_EXCEL as _XLData
{
  key _user.bname                   as end_user,
      _XLUser.status                as status,
      _XLUser.attachment            as Attachment,
      @Semantics.mimeType: true
      _XLUser.mimetype              as MimeType,
      _XLUser.filename              as Filename,
      @Semantics.user.createdBy: true
      _XLUser.local_created_by      as Local_Created_By,
      @Semantics.systemDateTime.createdAt: true
      _XLUser.local_created_at      as Local_Created_At,
      @Semantics.user.lastChangedBy: true
      _XLUser.local_last_changed_by as Local_Last_Changed_By,
      //local ETag field --> OData ETag
      @Semantics.systemDateTime.localInstanceLastChangedAt: true
      _XLUser.local_last_changed_at as Local_Last_Changed_At,
      //total ETag field
      @Semantics.systemDateTime.lastChangedAt: true
      _XLUser.last_changed_at       as Last_Changed_At,

      _XLData
}
where
  _user.bname = $session.user

Create Behavior Definitions Behavior Implementation and Behavior Projection

Now, let's create Behavior Definitions on top of the Parent Interface View and Behavior Projection on Parent Projection/ Consumption View we just created.

Behavior Definition – ZCDS_TOM_I_USER
managed implementation in class zbp_cl_cds_tom_i_user unique;
strict ( 2 );
with draft;

define behavior for ZCDS_TOM_I_USER alias XLHead
persistent table ztom_t_user
lock master
total etag end_user
draft table ztom_t_userd
//early numbering
authorization master ( instance )
etag master end_user
{
  create;
  update;
  delete;

  field ( readonly ) end_user;

  action ( features : instance ) downloadTemplate result [1] $self;
  action ( features : instance ) downloadData result [1] $self; //Needed in oDataV2 to download excel Data, for oDataV4 comment this

  // Logic to read excel data into into internal table and save to the child entity
  action ( features : instance ) uploadExcelData result [1] $self;

  association _XLData { create; with draft; }

  // Logic to trigger action uploadExcelData
  determination fields on modify { field Filename; }

  //Draft actions
  draft action Edit;
  draft action Activate;
  draft action Discard;
  draft action Resume;
  draft determine action Prepare;

}

define behavior for ZCDS_TOM_I_EXCEL alias XLData
persistent table ztom_t_excel
draft table ztom_t_exceld
lock dependent by _XLUser
authorization dependent by _XLUser
etag master New_Fkdat
{
  update;
  delete;
  field ( readonly ) end_user;

  association _XLUser { with draft; }

  //  action displayDocument result [1] $self; //IF WANT TO ADD A NEW ACTION

}
